videoData.title: How your nature photos can help protect wild animals
videoData.socialTitle: How your nature photos can help protect wild animals

nodes.whoTheyAre: Tanya Berger-Wolf is among the founders of the field of computational ecology, leading research at the unique intersection of computer science, wildlife biology and social sciences.
nodes.whyListen:
Tanya Berger-Wolf creates computational solutions to generate, collect, analyze and derive insight from data to answer questions and make decisions in ecology, environment and wildlife conservation. She is passionate about creating a human-AI partnership to address our planet’s greatest conservation challenges.

As a part of her work, she gets to hang out of an ultra-light airplane in Kenya, taking a hyper-stereo video of zebra populations and learning how to identify each one of them by the unique stripe pattern. She teaches a computer how to identify animals by their body patterns to provide accurate data for biodiversity monitoring. She is a professor at Ohio State University, a nonprofit director at Wild Me and a co-founder of a several big projects and fields of study (most recently, imageomics).

videoData.description: We're losing animal and plant species at such a swift, unprecedented rate that it's nearly impossible to keep up. Computational biologist Tanya Berger-Wolf demonstrates how harnessing the power of artificial intelligence and one of the internet's biggest resources -- public images and video -- supports the crucial collection of data to save threatened wildlife. Learn how your everyday photos, alongside the work of passionate citizen scientists, could help drive conservation decisions, and slow or even reverse damage to biodiversity worldwide.
videoData.socialDescription: We're losing animal and plant species at such a swift, unprecedented rate that it's nearly impossible to keep up. footnotes.annotation:
> “The International Unit for Conservation of Nature's Red List, is the official international organization that keeps track of the biodiversity of the world. And of the 130,000 species that they track out of the millions that are out there...”

According to the most recent estimates from the International Union for Conservation of Nature, there are [more than 138,300 species](https://www.iucnredlist.org/about/background-history) currently on their Red List of Threatened Species.

> “We have Wildbooks for 53 species from marine to terrestrial spanning the entire globe.” 

Wildbooks are now available for about 80 different species. For more information, [see here](https://www.wildme.org/#/platforms).

> “Wildbook was also used for the first ever full census of the entire species of the endangered Grevy’s zebra using photographs from ordinary people, just taking pictures for two days.” 

For more details, [see here](https://laikipia.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Great-Grevys-Rally-2016-Report-FINAL.pdf).

>“ ... So much so that Kenya Wildlife Service said this, how we're going to track the species from now on and do this every two years with an event known as the Great Grevy’s Rally. And so we repeated it in 2018 with more than a thousand people and also in 2020.”

For more information about Great Grevy’s Rally, [see here](https://www.grevyszebratrust.org/great-grevys-rally/).
